Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Chemical reaction of pollutants within fog droplets in the Eastern Yellow Sea
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fog droplets can impact air pollutants by providing a medium for their removal from the atmosphere, or their chemical reaction to form products that impact the climate system, human health, and ecosystem health differently. Specifically, solid and liquid products formed from aqueous reactions in fog droplets can aggregate to increase the number of particles available for cloud or fog droplet formation, and in turn, the lifetime and density of a cloud or fog. The chemicals present in atmospheric particles, fog, or cloud water will also determine their toxicity as they enter human respiratory systems or are deposited into ecosystems. Identifying and quantifying chemical reactions occurring within fog water is therefore important, particularly in regions where large amounts of pollutants have been measured, and fog events are frequent. This research will be conducted at Baengnyeong Island, Korea with the assistance of Dr. Taehyoung Lee of Hankuk University of Foreign Studies in Seoul. Baengnyeong Island is located in the Eastern Yellow Sea, where frequent fog events during the summer coincide with large amounts of gaseous and suspended solid or liquid pollutants from industrial, agricultural, desert (dust), and sea sources.

Chemical and physical measurements of fog water collected at Baengnyeong Island will be made to determine whether expected chemical reactions are occurring within the fog. Additional analyses will include analyses for anions including sulfate and nitrate, organic pollutants such as nitrophenols, and products of expected reactions such as small carboxylic acids. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was undertaken to investigate chemical reactions occurring within fog droplets in the Eastern Yellow Sea. It is understood that fog has many important roles in the atmosphere: (a) fog droplets can allow chemical degradation of pollutants and move pollutants between the atmosphere and ecosystems via loss to the ground (Collett et al., 2008); and (b) chemical reactions in fog can lead to the formation of aerosol particles, which impact climate and human and ecosystem health. The chemical reactions leading to removal of pollutants and formation of aerosol are known as oxidations. For carbonaceous molecules, oxidation is not well understood because of the complexity of the organic composition of the atmosphere, but often forms carboxylic acids. Carbonaceous pollutants can be removed from the atmosphere by oxidations in fog droplets, and the products can remain in the particle phase after a fog droplet evaporates, creating aerosol mass important for climate and air quality (Figure 1). It was anticipated that fog chemistry could be readily studied at Baengnyeong Island, South Korea (BYI) because of the high frequency of fog events during the summer and high concentrations of pollutants from industrial, agricultural, desert (dust), and sea sources (Lee et al., in review). We hypothesized that the oxidation of carbonaceous chemicals would occur within the fog at BYI and/or within cloud droplets during pollutant transport to BYI.

Fog water samples were collected from BYI and analyzed to show whether evidence of aqueous oxidation reactions was present. A Size-Fractionating Caltech Active Strand Cloudwater Collector (sf-CASCC; Figure 2) was used to collect fog water June 24th - July 29th, 2014. Droplets collected here were 4-16 μm in diameter (small) and >16 μm in diameter (large).

Air masses intercepted in fog water at BYI originated from several regions (NOAA HySPLIT; Figure 3), with local winds predominantly from the south. There were various source regions, including Northeastern China, the Sea of Japan, and Southeastern China. The recorded relative humidities of all fog air masses were high (>80%) during the three days prior to arrival at the study site, suggesting that aqueous oxidation (likely within clouds) during transit to BYI was probable. The fog densities and durations were sufficiently high that up to five 1-3 hour samples were collected from individual fog events, allowing some analysis of the chemical evolution of the fog water (Figure 4). However, physical processes such as evaporation and deposition of droplets onto ground create uncertainty in the time series for a given event. Thirty high volume (>50 mL) samples were collected and stored after aliquots for chemical analyses were taken, which will be oxidized in the lab at Colorado State University to simulate chemical oxidations in the real atmosphere (Boris et al., 2014).  Fog water collected at BYI was slightly acidic (mean = 3.9, range = 3.0 to 5.4 in the large droplets and mean = 3.8, range = 3.4 to 4.9) due to high concentrations of inorganic and organic chemicals, as expected based on previous studies of atmospheric chemistry around the Yellow Sea (Lee et al., in review). It is understood that fog has many important roles in the atmosphere: (a) fog droplets can allow chemical degradation of pollutants and move pollutants between the atmosphere and ecosystems via loss to the ground (Collett et al., 2008); and (b) chemical reactions in fog can lead to the formation of aerosol particles, which impact climate and human and ecosystem health. Fog water samples were collected from BYI and analyzed to show whether evidence of aqueous oxidation reactions was present. A Size-Fractionating Caltech Active Strand Cloudwater Collector (sf-CASCC; Figure 2) was used to collect fog water June 24th - July 29th, 2014. Droplets collected here were 4-16 μm in diameter (small) and >16 μm in diameter (large). Air masses intercepted in fog water at BYI originated from several regions (NOAA HySPLIT; Figure 3), with local winds predominantly from the south. There were various source regions, including Northeastern China, the Sea of Japan, and Southeastern China. The recorded relative humidities of all fog air masses were high (>80%) during the three days prior to arrival at the study site, suggesting that aqueous oxidation (likely within clouds) during transit to BYI was probable. The fog densities and durations were sufficiently high that up to five 1-3 hour samples were collected from individual fog events, allowing some analysis of the chemical evolution of the fog water (Figure 4). However, physical processes such as evaporation and deposition of droplets onto ground create uncertainty in the time series for a given event. Thirty high volume (>50 mL) samples were collected and stored after aliquots for chemical analyses were taken, which will be oxidized in the lab at Colorado State University to simulate chemical oxidations in the real atmosphere (Boris et al., 2014). Fog water collected at BYI was slightly acidic (mean = 3.9, range = 3.0 to 5.4 in the large droplets and mean = 3.8, range = 3.4 to 4.9) due to high concentrations of inorganic and organic chemicals, as expected based on previous studies of atmospheric chemistry around the Yellow Sea (Lee et al., in review). The total organic carbon (TOC) concentrations were within the range of the highest observed in fog and cloud droplets globally (Herckes et al., 2013) with a mean of 15.0 ppmC, ranging from 3.60 to 30.4 ppmC. The presence of high mass fractions of a diverse range of carboxylic acid species suggests that the constituents of the fog monitored in this field study had undergone substantial oxidation in the atmosphere prior to collection at BYI. The low concentrations of S(IV) and peroxides, and the high concentrations of SO4-2 also supported the hypothesis that oxidation occurred in the aqueous phase prior to arrival of the fog constituents at BYI.
